subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|虫|它|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p}}. {{zh-l|*它}} was also the original pictographic form of this character.

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{unk|zh}}. {{zh-ref|Starostin}} sets up {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*lăj||snake}} and compared {{lang|zh|蛇}} with {{cog|lus|hlai-ba||a species of snake}} and {{cog|kac||pə³³ lai³³|a species of iguana}}. Outside Sino-Tibetan, this was compared with {{cog|qfa-kms-pro|*dzuːi²||snake}} and {{cog|lic-pro|*ljaːɦ||snake}} (< Pre-Hlai ''*Cilaːɦ'').

Alternatively, {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} considered the Tai-Kadai forms to be possible borrowings from Chinese, and the above-cited Tibeto-Burman forms to be unrelated. In his view, a more likely relationship is with the {{IPAchar|/-lé/}} in {{cog|km|រលេ||[[sinuously]], in a [[twisting]] or [[wiggling]] manner (as a snake swimming)}}. In Old Chinese, this also provides the second syllable in {{och-l|委蛇|[[winding]]; [[compliant]]; [[graceful]]|id=1,3}}. {{m|zh|蛇||the winding thing}} is then a euphemism for common Sino-Tibetan {{och-l|虺|snake|id=3}} for taboo reasons.
